Executive

Summary
This report aims to describe my experiences and achievements at Türk Telekom,
where I worked as an intern. In addition, I have covered all the important components of the
company that I noticed during my internship.
Türk Telekom, the most prominent telecommunications company in Turkey, provides
a variety of engineering services. From the standpoint of industrial engineering, the
company's primary engineering endeavors center around the implementation and
administration of fiber optic networks, optimization of mobile and fixed internet services, data
center operations, and enhancing the efficacy of operational procedures. The company
applies the concepts of resource planning, quality control, process management, and
operational excellence to each of these tasks. The previously mentioned procedures involve
ongoing enhancements aimed at augmenting operational efficacy and guaranteeing the
uninterrupted and superior provision of telecommunication services.
I actively participated in all phases of these engineering efforts throughout my
internship. During the building of fiber optic networks, I was specifically involved in field
operations coordination and process planning. I have also contributed to projects focused on
process optimization and improving the performance of mobile phones. I also work directly
with customer service to help develop strategies to improve processes focused on customer
satisfaction. This allows me to evaluate the integration of technology and business processes.
The purpose of my internship is to examine the management and development of
business processes in communication, to gain experience in this field and to take part in
projects aimed at improving the process. For many, this prediction came true. I gained
valuable experience by being knowledgeable about field operations, participating actively in
every phase of the process, and putting continuous improvement strategies for engineering
processes into practice. In addition, my expectations from the internship were to learn as
much as possible using my own competence and to improve my analytical and verbal skills.
During the internship I helped many departments and visiting other departments helped me
to improve my communication skills and learn more about the process. The cus

tomer service
department was suitable for me to observe customer relations and the field operations
department was suitable for me to learn about management. While doing this job, I
experienced the machines the company uses and how they can be improved.
I learned a lot about how engineering processes are efficiently managed and
enhanced from this internship. Additionally, I saw how customer-oriented processes impact
customer pleasure and how operational efficiency is attained in them. These experiences
strengthened my engineering process optimization skills and provided a strong basis for my
future profession.
Key Words: Telecommunication, fiber optic networks, operational excellence, process
management, customer satisfaction, field operations coordination, process optimization, data
center operations, engineering processes, communication skills

1. Company and Sector
a. Overview of the Company and Sector
The company I work for is Türk Telekom Directorate. There are Türk Telekom Regional
Directorates in 11 different provinces in Turkey and 24 Türk Telekom Directorates (TM) in
Istanbul. I am doing my internship at Gayrettepe Türk Telekom Directorate. The address is
Gayrettepe, Vefabayırı Street, No:2, 34349 Beşiktaş/Istanbul. Türk Telekom's individual
number is 444 1 444, corporate number is 444 5 444. The web link is
https://www.turktelekom.com.tr .
With more than 180 years of

deep-rooted history, Türk Telekom (TT) is Turkey's first
integrated telecommunications operator. In 2015, Türk Telekomünikasyon A.Ş., TT Mobil
İletişim Hizmetleri A.Ş. and TTNET A.Ş. transitioned to a “customer-oriented” and integrated
structure by maintaining their legal entities in their current form and fully complying with the
legislation and regulations to which they are subject in order to respond to the rapidly
changing communication and technology needs of its customers in the most effective and
accurate manner. Türk Telekom, which has a wide service network and a rich product range
in individual and corporate services, brought together its mobile, internet, telephone and TV
products and services under the single brand 'Türk Telekom' as of January 2016.
Figure 1
Gayrettepe Turkish Telecommunication Institution is located in one of the central districts of
Istanbul and is responsible for the management of telecommunications and operations in the
region. It aims to contribute to Turkey's digital transformation with innovative solutions and
technological developments. Within this framework, Gayrettepe Directorate continuously
makes infrastructure investments to provide services in that region, to meet the needs of
businesses and individuals in the region, and to increase customer satisfaction.
As of March 31, 2024, Türk Telekom serves 17.4 million fixed access lines, 15.2 million
broadband, 3.1 million TV and 26.2 million mobile subscribers. With the vision of bringing
Turkey together with new technologies and accelerating the process of transformation into
an information society, Türk Telekom Group provides services in 81 provinces with 36,190
employees.
If I explain the services in some detail;
Fixed line services include fixed telephone services for homes and businesses. In mobile
communications, mobile telephony and data services are offered, while broadband internet
services are provided for homes and businesses through ADSL, VDSL and Fiber (GPON:
internet up to the apartment) options.
4

Digital television services are offered to users under the Tivibu brand with digital TV and IPTV
services. In addition, cloud computing and data center services are offered to corporate
customers through cloud and data center services.
Group companies include important subsidiaries such as TT Mobil, TTNET, Argela, Innova,
AssisTT. It also has companies operating in various sectors such as call center services, IT
solutions, online education software and financial technologies. These subsidiaries enhance
Türk Telekom's capacity to offer integrated services and provide a broad competence in
different technology areas.
60% of TT shares, shown with their capital in Table 1, belong to the Turkey Wealth Fund, 25%
to the Ministry of Treasury and Finance of the Republic of Turkey. The remaining 15% was
offered to the public.

With its large indoor area, Gayrettepe Türk Telekom Directorate consists of modern office
spaces, technical service rooms and customer service centers. Surrounding the building are
outdoor equipment and vehicle parking lots that support the technical infrastructure. There
are four switchboards connected to the Gayrettepe Telekom Directorate: one in Gayrettepe,
one in Beşiktaş and two in Levent. The switchboards in Levent are divided into Levent 1 and
Levent 2. In the indoor exchange, the system is fed by copper cable. In the outdoor power
plant, the system is distributed with fiber and then copper until the location to be served. In
order not to increase the losses in the copper cable too much, it should not exceed 100-150
meters, but the lines fed from the indoor power plant are sold to customers who do not
require high speed such as atm.
When looking at the number of employees, Gayrettepe Türk Telekom's group consists of
skilled workers, managers, support workers, experts, and specialists. Blue-collar workers,
known as professionals, are a group of 50 people who manage the company's operations.
White-collar workers are a group of about 20 professionals working in management, customer
service, office, and support areas. In addition, there are approximately 10 engineers working
on telecommunications, network infrastructure, software development and customer
solutions. These engineers play an important role in the development of Türk Telekom's
technological infrastructure and the improvement of customer solutions.
The total number of staff working at the Gayrettepe Türk Telekom Directorate is
approximately 100 people. However, there are also Türk Telekom Regional and General
Directorates in Gayrettepe. The number of employees working there is even higher.
Türk Telekom cooperates with many companies, both competitors and customers and
business partners. Its competitors include companies with ICTA licenses such as Türknet,
Türksat, Super Online, Turkcell, Vodafone and D-Smart. These companies compete in the
market by offering various telecommunications services. At the same time, in some cases they
cooperate to offer more comprehensive solutions to customers.
Türk Telekom's customer base is quite diverse. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs),
individual users, small office home office (SOHO) users, small and medium-sized enterprises
(SMEs), large-scale enterprises and public institutions constitute the strategic customer
segments. This wide range of customers reflects the diversity and scope of Türk Telekom's
services.
In terms of suppliers, Türk Telekom cooperates with telecommunications equipment and
technological infrastructure providers, software companies and infrastructure service
providers. These suppliers provide the hardware and software services necessary for Türk
Telekom to provide the best service to its customers. The necessity to procure a portion of
the capital expenditures from foreign companies and the need to finance the capital
expenditures with long-term and diversified funding sources cause Türk Telekom to carry
liabilities denominated in foreign currencies. In this respect, Türk Telekom has net liabilities
denominated in foreign currencies when hedging transactions are not taken into account and
may be exposed to foreign exchange rate risks due to fluctuating exchange rates, which may
have an impact on the financial statements.
Türk Telekom is one of the largest telecommunications companies in Turkey in terms of sales,
with an annual turnover of billions of Turkish liras. Gayrettepe Telekom Board of Directors
estimates annual sales to be in the hundreds of millions of TL.

b. Organization of the Company
Türk Telekom has various departments; these departments include board of directors, general
directorate, information technologies, strategy, investment and subsidiaries, corporate risk
and business, corporate communication and sales, technology, wholesale services general
directorates, regional directorate, Telekom directorate, technical operations, commercial
activities, field, management and support operations, individual and corporate customer
services, etc.
TT has a complex organizational structure. The main purpose of this structure is to ensure the
effective and efficient operation of the company in various service areas. Türk Telekom's
organizational structure is generally mechanistic. TT has hierarchical and functional
relationships between various departments. The CEO of the company is Ümit Önal. And there
are many deputy general managers. This is because Ümit Önal has several departments at his
disposal. Finance, Human Resources, Support Services, Purchasing Management, Individual
Sales, Corporate Sales, Wholesale Services, Legal and Regulatory, Network, Marketing and
Customer Experience, IT. The CEO and his deputies form the top management team of the
company. They make strategic decisions and set the overall direction of the company. The
main departments and regional directorates play a role in implementing the strategies. In this
report, I will talk about all the departments in TT directorates where I interned in more than
one directorate.

This system enables Türk Telekom to provide high quality and customer-oriented services.
Effective management of planning, forecasting, inventory, and logistics activities improves the
company's overall performance and customer satisfaction.
d. Professional and Ethical Responsibilities of Engineers
Engineers at the Gayrettepe Türk Telekom Directorate work by maintaining both their
technical competence and their commitment to ethical principles. This enables them to
perform their work to the highest standards and enhances the company's reputation and
customer satisfaction.
Professional Responsibilities
The primary professional responsibility of engineers is to keep their technical knowledge and
skills up to date and to use this knowledge in the most effective way on projects. Safety and
reliability are another important element that engineers always consider in their projects.
Ensuring safety in all projects, managing risks, and identifying potential hazards in advance
are among their priorities. Furthermore, engineers aim to increase the company's
competitiveness by constantly developing innovative solutions. This is achieved through the
integration of new technologies and the improvement of existing systems.
Ethical Responsibilities
Engineers should adhere to the principle of honesty and transparency in their business
processes, provide accurate information and give importance to these values in decision-
11

making processes. Environmental responsibility is another critical area of ethical
responsibility; engineers should contribute to sustainable projects by developing
environmentally friendly solutions. Social responsibility is also important; engineers fulfill
their social responsibilities by taking part in projects that benefit society. In terms of privacy
and security, they strictly adhere to privacy policies to protect customer information and
company data.
Professional and Ethical Standards Used in the Company
Türk Telekom has set certain professional and ethical standards that engineers must comply
with. These standards include basic ethical principles such as honesty, reliability, respect, and
fairness. There is an ethics committee within the company for the implementation of ethical
rules and employees are encouraged to report possible ethical violations to this committee.
Compliance with company policies and zero tolerance for discrimination and unfair treatment
are essential. This code guides the professional behavior of engineers and creates a fair
working environment in the workplace.
Tasks performed by engineers
Engineers perform various tasks to ensure the smooth operation of Turkey's
telecommunications technical infrastructure. Network design and management is one of
these activities; Engineers are also responsible for the operation, maintenance, and repair of
data center management. This ensures the uninterrupted operation of the data center and
protects the security of user data.
Industrial engineers play a key role in process improvement and efficiency enhancement
efforts. They analyze the company's operational processes, optimize workflows, and ensure
the most efficient use of resources. They also develop methodologies for project
management, controlling costs and improving processes. These activities increase the overall

efficiency of the company, while also contributing to cost savings.
Project management is among the important tasks of engineers. Planning, executing, and
controlling the costs of telecommunication projects is critical to their successful completion.
Engineers also play an active role in resolving customer issues and providing technical support
to field teams. These activities are an important part of the company's efforts to increase
customer satisfaction.
As a result, the engineers working at the Gayrettepe Türk Telekom Directorate aim to improve
the quality and reliability of the company's telecommunications services by combining their
technical competence and ethical responsibility. Thanks to their professional skills and
commitment to ethical values, these engineers succeed in meeting the expectations of both
the company and its customers.
12

2. Summer Practice Description
I present below the main list and descriptions of the activities I carried out at Türk Telekom
during my summer internship. I have also tried to include relevant technical information and
references about the equipment, tools, processes I observed or used.
Commercial Operations and Customer Service
I participated in individual and corporate customer service processes in Commercial Activities.
Individual customer service was also divided into two. One was responsible for sales and the
other for after-sales processes. I experienced both. I conducted after-sales customer
satisfaction surveys and analyzes. At the same time, together with the employees, we
evaluated customer complaints and offered solutions.
The relevance of this department to my main work is that improving customer satisfaction
and service quality directly contributes to the service improvement and process optimization
areas of industrial engineering.
Customer service professionals are very interested in seeing how customer relations are
handled in the real world. It has especially improved my ability to deal with difficult customers
and find solutions quickly.
I have gained experience in customer satisfaction and complaint handling.
I gained knowledge on improving service processes and increasing efficiency. Most
importantly, it helped me understand the importance of customer relations and how to
establish a one-to-one relationship with customers during work.
Field Operations and Access
There were parts of this unit where I helped more. I had the chance to monitor the daily
operations of field teams and provide support. I participated in the processes of laying fiber
optic and copper cables, solving field cabinet failures. I also observed fault detection and
repair processes.
Field operations directly contribute to the process management and operational efficiency of
industrial engineering.
For me, it was a very interesting and instructive experience to work with the technical teams
in this unit and observe the field operations on site. It was also quite physically challenging.
I gained technical knowledge about fiber optic, internet connection processes and I learned
to follow the management of the team doing these in the field from the Gant chart.
Planning and Field Management Support
In this department, I prepared and monitored the work plans of the field teams, as well as
resource management and logistics planning. Every day, I prepared and evaluated the
performance evaluation reports of all teams and employees, and as a result, necessary
information was given to the necessary people, and when necessary, necessary conversations
were held with people who were in a very bad situation.
Planning and resource management is one of the core areas of industrial engineering and
these processes are directly related to increasing productivity and operational improvements.
The process of preparing work plans and effectively managing field teams was challenging as
it required detailed planning.
I gained practical knowledge and experience in planning and resource management. I
improved my performance evaluation and reporting skills.
Network and Technical Operations
We examined the working principles of technologies such as ADSL, VDSL, FTTB, FTTC, FTTH.
We received many trainings on router and switch configurations, etc.
13

Network management and technical operations directly contribute to system optimization
and technology integration in industrial engineering.
It was interesting to see and learn about new technologies and the basis of technological
things that are being renewed and progressing. It was also quite challenging to learn and apply
the technical details.
But I gained in-depth knowledge about network technologies and equipment.
During my summer internship, the experiences, and observations I gained at TT greatly
improved my professional knowledge and skills. From customer service to field operations,
from planning to network management, I reinforced my theoretical knowledge in the field of
industrial engineering with practical applications. This process made great contributions to
me both personally and professionally and was a valuable experience for my future career
goals. After such an overview, I will talk a little bit about the terms I learned.
Router (Two Wide Area Network (WAN) communications): A router is a network device that
routes data packets between two or more networks. Routers enable data communication
between networks by forwarding data packets through the optimal path based on their source
and destination IP addresses. Two-WAN communication means that a router manages data
transmission between two different wide area networks (WANs). This can be used for things
like redundancy of internet connectivity or load balancing. Routers are critical to ensuring that
wide area networks communicate efficiently and reliably.
F/O (fiber optic): Fiber Optic Cable: Fiber optic cables are made of glass or plastic fibers that
allow light to pass through them. Fiber optic cables are resistant to electromagnetic
interference in data transmission and can transmit large data at high speeds. They are widely
used in communication and Internet services.
FTTB (fiber to the building): Fiber to the Building: FTTB is a configuration in which fiber optic
cable is brought to the basement or telecommunications room of a building. From there, users
inside the building can access the internet via copper cables or Ethernet cables. This
configuration is common for large buildings such as high-rise apartment buildings and
business centers.
FTTC (fiber to the curb): FTTC is a configuration where fiber optic cable is brought to a street
corner or a central cabinet. From there, users' homes or businesses are connected with copper
cable or other types of cabling. FTTC offers a lower-cost solution, while still enabling data
transmission at high speeds.
FTTH (fiber to the home): FTTH is a configuration where fiber optic cable is brought directly
to the user's home. This offers the fastest internet connection speeds and is one of the most
technologically advanced internet connection methods available today. Users can get the best
performance and fastest speeds with this method.
Switching Device: A switch is a network device that enables devices within a local area
network (LAN) to communicate with each other. The switch manages and optimizes network
traffic by routing data packets to the correct destination. This ensures efficient and reliable
data transmission within the network.
LAN (Local Area Network): LAN is a type of network in which devices located within a specific
geographical area (usually a building or campus) communicate with each other. LAN provides
14

high-speed data transmission and facilitates operations such as file sharing and printer sharing
between devices.
WAN (Wide Area Network): WAN is a type of network where devices communicate with each
other over large geographical areas (cities, countries, even continents). WAN refers to large-
scale ne

tworks such as the Internet and connects LANs to each other, creating a larger
communication network.
ADSL (Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line): ADSL is a technology that provides a high-speed
internet connection over existing telephone lines. The term “asymmetric” means that the
download speed (download) is higher than the upload speed (upload). ADSL is commonly used
for broadband internet connection.
VDSL (Very High Speed Digital Subscriber Line): VDSL is a DSL technology that offers higher
speeds than ADSL. It provides data transmission at very high speeds over short distances. VDSL
is particularly suitable for applications that require high bandwidth, such as video streaming
and large file downloads.
XDSL (Generic Name for DSL Technologies): XDSL is the generic name for DSL technologies and
covers different types of DSL such as ADSL, VDSL, SDSL. DSL technologies provide broadband
internet connection over telephone lines.
DSL (Digital Subscriber Line): DSL is a broadband internet technology that provides high-speed
data transmission over existing telephone lines. DSL uses telephone lines to provide internet
access and does not interfere with phone calls during data transmission.
SSG (Service Selection Gateway): SSG is a network device that allows users to select and
connect to various services from an Internet Service Provider (ISP). SSG performs
authentication, authorization, and account management to enable users to use specific
services. The device allows users to choose between different speed packages, security
services, or other additional services, especially general services.
HGW (home gateway): An HGW is a device that enables in-home devices to connect to the
Internet. It usually combines the functions of a modem and a router. The HGW manages
internet access for devices within the home and provides a secure network connection.
• Activity Analysis
As an industrial engineer intern, I would like to first talk about the general operation etc. Then
I will explain the specific activities I have done.
The activities performed are the realization of physical and definitional operations of internet,
fixed home phone, pay phone, IP TV and satellite requests or malfunctions of customers in
Gayrettepe TM area. In short, network operation is performed. The customer reports the
customer's request or malfunction through one of the online call center, office, or dealer
channels. The relevant unit creates an order or fault work order. These work orders are
controlled by Türk Telekom systems. And they are reflected on the GANT screens of field
operation teams. (Figure 7) The management of the Gant screen is carried out by switchboard
supervisors. Teams intervene in the works that fall on the Gant screen on their mobile devices.
The operation is carried out by ensuring customer satisfaction and uninterrupted operation
of the network in line with the targets set by the General Directorate. In order for this
operation to continue without interruption of access, the access engineer and field operation
engineer provide control, support, material requests, team needs, planning, investment,
15

instant solution suggestions and long-term solution suggestions and improvements.
Improvement studies are carried out. In line with the targets set by the General Directorate,
directorate values are largely monitored by engineers.
The main topics in network operation are as follows:
Location discovery (identification of nearby access points and determination of routes)
Determining the profit and loss pillars of the project budget resulting from the planning and
approving or rejecting the investment
Collecting orders for approved projects (Commercial activities)
Completion and uninterrupted continuity of the physical connections of the location opened
to access
Problematic teams are identified as a result of reporting. The works that are not realized
within the target are questioned, the deficiencies of the team or the aspects that can be
improved are identified and interviews and field visits are made with the teams. At the same
time, whether the teams are working in accordance with OHS (occupational health and safety)
standards is checked by managers through audits. Access systems that malfunction due to
external factors are intervened and the malfunction is eliminated. The aspects that can be
improved are addressed and measures are taken to prevent recurrence. Maintenance is
carried out periodically in order for the network to run smoothly.
How are targets tracked?
Since all work is carried out through WMS (Workforce Management System - Gant chart),
reports are shared in excel format using the WMS. Through the systems that WMS
communicates with in the background, raw data-based tracking of targets is carried out.
With the calculation methods determined by the General Directorate, the score of each team
constitutes the average of the power plants, and the average of the power plants constitutes
the average of the directorate. The average of the directorates also constitutes the average
of the Istanbul regional directorate. As Gayrettepe directorate, the goal is to always be in the
top 3. The control of these is followed by the operations manager and engineers.
How to work on a GANT screen?
In order for the Gant screen to work, first a work area is created. There are 4 work areas
(Beşiktaş, Gayrettepe, Levent 1 - 2 power plants) for Gayrettepe TM. Team codes are entered
into these work areas. The work ability that each code can do is added to each code. In
addition, the working area of each team code is determined. (neighborhood, street etc.) For
example, when a fiber failure occurs, the system first looks at the work area, then the work
area and finally the team codes with fiber capability in that area. It assigns it to the gant chart
of the relevant team with an appointment gap in the GANT chart. (Figure 7) The appointment

density in the GANT chart is monitored.

3. Conclusions
During my 20-day internship at Türk Telekom, I worked in many different departments from
customer service to field operations and improved myself in this process. The knowledge and
experience I gained became very important for me. I had the opportunity to work with the
customer service department in commercial activities, and with the field management
support team, field supervisors, HAES team and Access team in field operations. I also received
training on Next Generation Network (NGN) in the RSMC department at Türk Telekom
Regional Directorate.
Thanks to these activities, I had the opportunity to closely observe the operational processes
in the telecommunications sector and understand the dynamics in the sector. My experience
in the project field has given me a deep understanding of the importance of site management,
teamwork and infrastructure. When necessary, I use Office applications, TTOYS, KOKPİTT, GIS,
WMS etc. programs on my computer. By doing this kind of work, I improved my Office
Application skills, etc. and gained writing skills by preparing reports based on them. In
commercial activities, I observed the critical role of customer satisfaction and service quality
in the success of the company. I improved my communication skills by observing how to
communicate with customers, etc.
The experiences I gained during my internship included system installation and maintenance,
network management, and customer complaint resolution. These experiences enhanced my
ability to identify problems from an engineering perspective, manage problem-solving
processes, and develop a customer-centric approach. In addition, the working conditions of
the engineers I observed in the field showed me the importance of teamwork and constant
communication. However, I observed that there was a problem when the field supervisors
were managing the teams in the field. When the team went to the customer appointment
written in the gant chart, there was a lot of failure to reach the customer. And the field
supervisors had to run after the customers and reach them many times. This reduced the
number of jobs to be done during the day. Both time was wasted and work was disrupted. For
this reason, I thought that if the customer who makes an appointment is not at home at that
time, a system of either not being able to make an appointment for 15 days or making a
certain amount of payment on the second appointment should be created, and I also talked
to the authorities to put this into operation.
Despite its large market size, the telecommunications sector has a dynamic structure that has
to keep pace with constantly evolving technology. In order to adapt to these rapid changes,
the Company continuously follows and implements technological innovations. However, the
main challenges in the sector include the cost of infrastructure investments and rapidly
changing customer expectations.
I believe that in the next 5-10 years, technologies such as big data analytics, artificial
intelligence, the internet of things, and 5G will be increasingly used in the business world and
productivity will increase. I also believe that technologies such as 3D printing,
nanotechnology, and robotics will revolutionize products and services. The integration of
these technologies will provide the company with a competitive advantage and encourage
customers to innovate.

a. Impact
The engineering work I saw during my tenure at Türk Telekom’s RSMC (Network System
Operations Management - Carrier) department can be related to many situations:
Global Impact:
Digital Communications and Global Connectivity: Türk Telekom's fiber optic networks and
broadband services are part of the global communications infrastructure, accelerating the
flow of information around the world. This facilitates international cooperation, trade, and
education. Furthermore, this infrastructure supports integration into the global digital
economy, helping to bridge the digital divide between countries.
Economic Impact:
Cost Savings and Efficiency: The use of fiber optic technology speeds up data transmission
while reducing energy costs and maintenance requirements. This could lead to significant
performance gains. Türk Telekom’s investment in this area will contribute to Turkey’s
economic growth, increasing the popularity of digital services and the country’s
competitiveness.
Environmental Impact:
Energy Efficiency and Waste Reduction: Fiber optic cables consume less energy than
traditional copper cables, which reduces the company's carbon footprint. In addition, the
longer lifespan of these cables also reduces the amount of electronic waste. Türk Telekom's
environmentally friendly engineering solutions contribute to achieving sustainable
development goals.
Social Impact:
Digital Inclusion and Social Development: Türk Telekom's broadband services contribute to
reducing social inequalities by increasing digital access, especially in rural and socio-
economically disadvantaged areas. Such services facilitate access to basic services such as
education and healthcare, thereby improving the quality of life across society. In addition, the
company's social responsibility projects for the community promote digital literacy,
encouraging individuals to access and use modern technology.
b. Team Work
During my field operations at Türk Telekom, I had the chance to closely observe the critical

role of teamwork. Field operations are a dynamic process that requires team members with
different specializations to work in harmony, and dispatchers play a key role in this process.
The field team usually consists of field technicians, support staff and dispatchers. Dispatchers
are at the center of field operations, making strategic decisions and providing direction to
ensure the team is working efficiently and effectively in the field. Field technicians perform
the necessary technical operations at customer locations or in designated areas. Support
personnel provide the necessary material and logistical

support to ensure uninterrupted
operations.
In this process, the leadership skills and teamwork abilities of dispatch supervisors come to
the fore. Supervisors ensure that each member of the field team clearly understands their
22

duties and fulfills them with the highest efficiency. During field operations, instant
information sharing and cooperation between tea

m members is critical for the success of
operations. Dispatch supervisors guide the team and provide support when necessary to
ensure that problems are resolved quickly, and the workflow runs smoothly.
This organization increases the team's confidence while achieving timely and successful
results. Regional teams are able to work in harmony towards a single goal and keep customer
satisfaction at the highest level. One of the most important lessons I learned during this
process is that teamwork is the key to success, even in challenging and unpredictable
environments such as field work.
